lead_paragraph: GROSS--Ronald Martin, was born in Cleveland, OH on October 19, 1933. He died at home in Stamford, CT surrounded by his family on January 31, 2016 at the age of 82. Ron was the son of Pearl Dolinsky Gross and Herman Gross. He spent his childhood in Lima, OH where he graduated from Lima Central High School. He attended Ohio State University, earning a bachelor's degree in Biology in 1955. After graduation, Ron worked at Battelle Memorial Institute decoding sensitive intelligence information for the United States government. He graduated from Harvard Business School in 1960. Subsequently, his professional life was marked by over 50 years of distinguished business and civic accomplishment. Ron spent his entire professional career in the pulp and paper industry. He served in various roles at Champion International from 1960-1968. In 1968 he moved his family to Vancouver, Canada where he became the C.E.O. of Canadian Cellulose Corporation at the age of 39. His accomplishments there were noted in an article on the front page of The New York Times business section in 1977, "Dramatic Turnaround of a Canadian Pulp Enterprise." While in Canada, he served on the boards of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, the Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada, the Canadian Forestry Association of British Columbia, and the Advisory Board, Division of International Business Studies, University of British Columbia. In 1978, he moved his family to Stamford, CT, starting a long career with ITT Rayonier where he served as C.E.O. for 17 years. During his tenure as C.E.O., he successfully spun off Rayonier, Inc. as an independent, public entity on the NYSE. Towards the end of his business career he served on several corporate boards, including the Brinks Company, Corn Products International, and Lukens Steel. He was a long time member of the board of directors of the American Forest and Paper Association and was a member of the Investment Policy Advisory Committee of the U.S. Trade Representative. He served as the Chairman of Rayonier's board until 1998. Ron's life was filled with civic and charitable endeavors. He served as President of Congregation Beth Israel in Vancouver, Canada and of Temple Beth El in Stamford, CT. He also served as President of the United Jewish Federation of Greater Stamford, New Canaan and Darien, served on the board of the United Way and as Chairman of the U.S. Savings Bond Campaign for Fairfield County. Ron is survived by his wife of 53 years Grecia Levin Gross, son Bradley Gross and his wife Stephanie Phillips of New York City, son Dr. Bennett Gross and his wife Jacqueline Sherman of San Diego, CA, brother James Gross of Tryon, NC, and his three grandchildren, Eli, Anderson, and Benjamin. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society. 1/3
